vehicles.description: A fictional LRV from Japan, built in 1999, in RNET gray livery. Based on the Tokyu 300 Series.

vehicles.description: A fictional LRV from Japan, built in 1999, in RNET gray livery. Based on the Tokyu 300 Series.

vehicles.name: R-net Stadler FLIRT 3 Trailer
vehicles.description: A Stadler FLIRT 3 adaptation of the DB BR 423 created as reference to the unique train on Szandor's former daily commute

vehicles.description: A Stadler FLIRT 3 adaptation of the DB BR 423 created as reference to the unique train on Szandor's former daily commute

vehicles.description: A Stadler FLIRT 3 adaptation of the DB BR 423 created as reference to the unique train on Szandor's former daily commute

sebluestripe_377.name: British Rail Class 377 SouthEastern (Dark Blue stripe w/Light Blue doors)

seyellowstripe_377.name: British Rail Class 377 SouthEastern (Yellow stripe w/Yellow doors)

seyellowdoor_377.name: British Rail Class 377 SouthEastern (No stripe w/Yellow doors)

sebluedoor_377.name: British Rail Class 377 SouthEastern (No stripe w/Light Blue doors)

seroyaltunbridgewells_377.name: British Rail Class 377 SouthEastern (Royal Tunbridge Wells [one-off special livery])

lion.name: 71-911 /Lionet
lion.description: 71-911EM Lionet is a Russian four-axle four-door single-sided tram with a completely low level floor, created by LLC PC Transport Systems at the facilities of Tver Carriage Works. The first 100% low-floor tram car in the CIS.

vityazm.name: 71-931 -/Vityaz-M
vityazm.description: 71-931 Vityaz (lit.'Knight') is a Russian three-unit six-axle 100% low-floor tram car created by LLC PC Transport Systems and manufactured in cooperation by PK TS and Transmashholding at the facilities of the Tver Carriage Works. Currently exists in two versions: the basic model Vityaz and 71-931M Vityaz-M modification with modified front and rear mask, different interior and Russian-designed traction motors. In operation in St. Petersburg, Krasnodar and Moscow's Bauman, Oktyabrskoye and Rusakov depots.

vityazjocker.name: 71-931 - ()/Vityaz-M (Gray)
vityazjocker.description: 71-931 Vityaz (lit.'Knight') is a Russian three-unit six-axle 100% low-floor tram car created by LLC PC Transport Systems and manufactured in cooperation by PK TS and Transmashholding at the facilities of the Tver Carriage Works. Currently exists in two versions: the basic model Vityaz and 71-931M Vityaz-M modification with modified front and rear mask, different interior and Russian-designed traction motors. In operation in St. Petersburg, Krasnodar and Moscow's Bauman, Oktyabrskoye and Rusakov depots.

vityazwhblue.name: 71-931 - (-)/Vityaz-M (White-blue)
vityazwhblue.description: 71-931 Vityaz (lit.'Knight') is a Russian three-unit six-axle 100% low-floor tram car created by LLC PC Transport Systems and manufactured in cooperation by PK TS and Transmashholding at the facilities of the Tver Carriage Works. Currently exists in two versions: the basic model Vityaz and 71-931M Vityaz-M modification with modified front and rear mask, different interior and Russian-designed traction motors. In operation in St. Petersburg, Krasnodar and Moscow's Bauman, Oktyabrskoye and Rusakov depots.

lm2008.description: LM-2008 (71-153) is a Russian passenger single-section four-axle one-way tram with a low-floor platform in the middle of the car. The proportion of the low floor is 40%.

tatrakt4dtm.name: Tatra KT4Dtm
tatrakt4dtm.description: Tatra KT4 is the name of a four-axle type articulated tramcar developed by the Czech firm KD Tatra. The first pre-production vehicles entered service in Potsdam in 1975, with the first production vehicles in 1977. A total of 1,747 units were built, with initial deliveries to East Germany and later to the USSR and SFR Yugoslavia. KT4 variants were built for both standard gauge and metre gauge tramways.

kt4vbb.name: Tatra KT4DM Brandenburg
kt4vbb.description: Tatra KT4 is the name of a four-axle type articulated tramcar developed by the Czech firm KD Tatra. The first pre-production vehicles entered service in Potsdam in 1975, with the first production vehicles in 1977. A total of 1,747 units were built, with initial deliveries to East Germany and later to the USSR and SFR Yugoslavia. KT4 variants were built for both standard gauge and metre gauge tramways.

kt4bvg.name: Tatra KT4DM Berlin
kt4bvg.description: Tatra KT4 is the name of a four-axle type articulated tramcar developed by the Czech firm KD Tatra. The first pre-production vehicles entered service in Potsdam in 1975, with the first production vehicles in 1977. A total of 1,747 units were built, with initial deliveries to East Germany and later to the USSR and SFR Yugoslavia. KT4 variants were built for both standard gauge and metre gauge tramways.

ktm31.name: 71-631 -31 SPB/
ktm31.description: KTM-31 (71-631) is an articulated six-axle tram manufactured by the Ust-Katavsky Carriage Works. operated in St. Petersburg, Samara, Krasnodar and in Daugavpils.

lvs2009.description: LVS-2009 (71-154) is a three-section articulated passenger tram with partially low floor manufactured by the St. Petersburg Tramway Mechanical Plant. Operated in Volgograd and in Kyiv. Due to the bankruptcy of PTMZ, further production of this model has been stopped.

ktm23.description: The 71-623 is a 40% low floor, one way tram built by Ust-Katav Wagon-Building Plant. Has been xported to Kazakhstan, Ukraine and Latvia.

ktm23spb.name: 71-623 -23 /SPB
ktm23spb.description: The 71-623 is a 40% low floor, one way tram built by Ust-Katav Wagon-Building Plant. Has been xported to Kazakhstan, Ukraine and Latvia. This version is operated in St. Petersburg, Russia.

ktm19.description: The 71-619 (colloquially KTM-19) is the modern Russian four-axle high-floor motor tramcar. These rail vehicles are produced at the Ust'-Katav Wagon-building plant. Trams are exlupated in most Russian cities, as well as in Uzbekistan, Ukraine and Kakhastan

gothat57.name: Gotha T57
gothat57.description: THIS TRAM WILL BE REMOVED SOON! Gotha T57 is a two-axle wagon for two-way traffic, produced by the national enterprise 'Gotha Wagon Works' of Gotha (Germany). Operated in Evpatoria, Molochnoye village, Vinnitsa, Woltersdorf, Bad-Schandau, Nauburg, Bursa, Istanbul and others

variolf.name: Vario LF - /Plzen
variolf.description: Vario LF is a modification of the Tatra T3 tram produced from the early 1960s to the early 1990s. Operated in a number of cities in the Czech Republic, Russia, Slovakia and Tajikistan

variolfred.name: Vario LF - /Red
variolfred.description: Vario LF is a modification of the Tatra T3 tram produced from the early 1960s to the early 1990s. Operated in a number of cities in the Czech Republic, Russia, Slovakia and Tajikistan

variolfmos.name: Vario LF - /Moscow
variolfmos.description: Vario LF is a modification of the Tatra T3 tram produced from the early 1960s to the early 1990s. Operated in a number of cities in the Czech Republic, Russia, Slovakia and Tajikistan

variolf2murs.name: Vario LF2 - Brno w/Plug Doors
variolf2murs.description: VarioLF2 is a Czech partially low-floor, articulated two-section tram. Structurally, the LF2 is based on previous LF models. Exlpuated in Brno and Ostrava

lm57.name: -57 /Stilyaga
lm57.description: The LM-57 is the Soviet motor four-axle tramcar. First prototype of this vehicle was built in 1957 (hence the 57 in the name) at the Leningrad Wagon Repair Plant. 'LM' means Leningrad Motor tramcar. The VARZ produced nearly 800 LM-57s in 19571968. The LM-57 had a nickname Stilyaga meaning The Dandy for its external appearance. LM-57 tramcars worked in Leningrad, Kiev, Tashkent, Gorky, Magnitogorsk, Kazan, Saratov, Arkhangelsk and Nizhny Tagil.

astra.name: Skoda 03t Astra
astra.description: The koda 03 T (sold as koda Astra) is a three-section low-floor tram developed by koda Transportation and Inekon Group. The 03 T is uni-directional and has a low floor over half of its length. The front and rear sections, under which the wheels are placed, have a high floor; the middle section, between these, has a low floor. Operated in cities in the Czech Republic.

x.name: (retro)
x.description: Kh (Russian: ) was the class of double axled high-floor tramcars, which were built in Soviet Union in interbellum period. First vehicles were built in 1927 and delivered to Kharkov, Ukraine. A small number of surviving cars are preserved for museum purposes in Moscow, Nizhniy Novgorod, Saratov and a few other cities.

rt8d5m.name: Tatra RT8D5M
rt8d5m.description: Tatra RT8D5M is a class of high-floor light rail vehicles built by Czech tram manufacturer KD Tatra. It is currently used on the Manila MRT Line 3 and were the last vehicles made by KD Tatra before it was taken over by Siemens.

vario3.name: Vario LF3
vario3.description: VarioLF3 is a Czech eight-axle articulated tramcar with variable floor level. It was developed by the Pragoimex plant. The share of low floor is 50 %. Tram is designed for operation on urban high-speed tram lines. Operated in Ostrava.

forcity.name: Skoda 15T ForCity Alpha
forcity.description: koda 15T (also known as koda ForCity Alfa) is a 100% low-floor multiple-unit tram developed by VUKV a.s. and built by koda Transportation in Pilsen for the Prague tram network. koda ForCity won the bidding process of the Prague transport company for 250 new trams in 2005.

forcity_praha.name: Skoda 15T1 ForCity Riga
forcity_praha.description: koda 15T (also known as koda ForCity Alfa) is a 100% low-floor multiple-unit tram developed by VUKV a.s. and built by koda Transportation in Pilsen for the Prague tram network. In May 2008 koda made a contract with the Riga transport company (Latvia) for delivery of 20 trams (with option for another 32)

lvs2005.description: LVS-2005 (71-152) is a one-sided six-axle articulated tramcar with variable floor level. LVS-2005 was developed at the St. Petersburg Tram and Mechanical Plant in 2005. Operated in St. Petersburg and Barnaul

mgt6d.name: MGT6D
mgt6d.description: The MGT6D (DUEWAG low-floor car) is a type of low-floor articulated tramcar with a low-floor ratio of around 63 to 70 per cent. This type was developed from 1988 for the Kasseler Verkehrs-Gesellschaft. It was the first series-produced vehicle to have single-wheel bogies (EEF) based on the Frederich system. The vehicle consists of a centre section with two EEF bogies and two end sections mounted on top, each with a two-axle motor bogie.

lm99k.description: LM-99 (71-134) was a Russian passenger one-way four-axle tramcar built at the St. Petersburg Tramway Mechanical Plant (PTMZ).  The first prototype was built in 1999, serial production began in 2000 and was completed in the second half of 2008. early versions of LM-99 were nicknamed 'grasshopper' (green colouring) for similar reasons. LM-99 trams operate in St. Petersburg, Kemerovo, Kolomna, Novosibirsk, Osinniki, Salavat, Smolensk, Taganrog, Ust-Kamenogorsk, Khabarovsk.

pesa120na.name: PESA 120Na 'Swing'
pesa120na.description: PESA Swing is a tram manufactured by a Polish company PESA in Bydgoszcz. It is a 100% low-floor, five-section vehicle based on the 120N model. The first company to order PESA 120Na Swing trams was Warsaw Tramway, which ordered 186 units. The delivery started in summer 2010 and it is expected that by the end of 2012 already about 100 units will have been delivered. operated in cities in Poland, Bulgaria, Hungary, Romania and Russia. !!Thanks in favour of 1,000 downloads!!

jazz.name: Pesa 128N Duo 'Jazz' (7 cars)
jazz.description: The Pesa Jazz is a family of low floor, articulated and multiple carriage trams by Pesa SA which have been manufactured since 2013. The trams are currently serving the cities of Gdask and Warsaw.

jazz5.name: Pesa 128N Duo 'Jazz' (5 cars)
jazz5.description: The Pesa Jazz is a family of low floor, articulated and multiple carriage trams by Pesa SA which have been manufactured since 2013. The trams are currently serving the cities of Gdask and Warsaw.

bogatyrm.name: 71-923 -/Bogatyr-M
bogatyrm.description: 71-923M Bogatyr-M is an articulated four-axle tram with a fully low floor level, built by PK Transport Systems at the Tver Carriage Works. Produced from 2019 to the present day. As of 2025, in operation in St. Petersburg, Saratov, Cherepovets and Ulan-Ude, running in Chelyabinsk and Moscow.

nevsky.name: 71-932 /Nevsky
nevsky.description: 71-932 Nevsky is a three-section six-axle shuttle-type tram with a fully low floor level, designed by PK Transport Systems. It is produced at the Nevsky Plant of Electric Transport. It is the successor of the Vityaz tram and its modernisation Vityaz-M.

bkm843m.name: /BKM 84300M /Saint-Petersburg
bkm843m.description: AKSM-84300M (also BKM-84300M)  a low-floor three-section tram produced by the Belorussian plant Belkommunmash. It is designed for operation on tram lines with a track gauge of 1524 mm. The car with two motor and one support bogie and electronic control system on IGBT modules for AC traction motors is available in single- and double-sided modifications. The model was discontinued due to the launch of updated 845 model. This is the first modern three-section low-floor tramway in the CIS to be brought to series and regular operation. Tram is in operation in Belarus, Russia and Ukraine.

varyag.name: 71-922 /Varyag
varyag.description: 71-922 Varyag is a three-section four-axle tram with a fully low floor level, built by PK Transport Systems. It was designed to pass Through outsized curves as well as to operate on less congested routes. Unfortunately, due to the high cost, smaller cities refused to purchase the tram, while larger ones (like Moscow or St. Petersburg) preferred the more spacious 71-931 Vitiyaz. The tram was created in only 1 copy.
